awd_titl_txt: Conference: Enabling the Implementation of Integrated and Scalable Smart Cities
awd_abstract_narration:
Less than ten years ago, the promise of smart cities seemed endless and ripe with opportunity to improve citizen quality of life through application of technologies such as cameras and Internet of Things (IoT) sensors with a layer of artificial intelligence (AI) to streamline and optimize operations and outcomes. Since that time, the shine has worn off. Projects often do not go past the pilot stage, are application and context specific, are not implemented at scale, do not explicitly integrate community input during design, planning or operation, and largely consist of isolated platforms or systems of operation without integration. To address these issues, we will hold a workshop focusing on the significant technical, policy and socioeconomic challenges with respect to the integration and scalability of smart city technologies, approaches and/or deployments in real-world settings. Current barriers to integration and/or scaling of the above are likely also related to current policy/regulations, financing, and workforce gaps and as such, they will be considered to inform the research agenda. The workshop will discuss potential solutions to the scalability and integration challenges to help guide future NSF investments in smart cities deployments.

The workshop will convene a series of online “listening sessions” with diverse stakeholders from around the United States, including rural, urban and suburban perspectives, to better inform our understanding of the aforementioned challenges. We will use these listening sessions to develop a set of research questions which will be refined in an in-person workshop where we will discuss potential solutions to the scalability and integration challenges (technical and non-technical) to help guide future NSF investments in smart cities deployments. This workshop will foster convergence by engaging participants from academia, government, non-profits, community advocacy, private property owners, civic agencies, and industry, across a range of smart city applications relative to different infrastructure systems. For each of these application areas (such as energy, transportation, water, etc.), we will bring together expertise from engineering, public policy, computer science, and social and decision science, as well as direct input from community leaders and partners. The main intellectual merit of this workshop will be the development of a summary report outlining a multi-disciplinary research agenda (gaps, questions, and proposed research tasks) to overcome the scalability and integration challenges identified throughout the multi-stakeholder discussions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to address the challenge of integrating and scaling smart cities technology and ?help shine a light on challenges inhibiting integration and scalability including identifying common problems/patterns that need to be addressed, as well as how to address them in an integrated fashion.? The project proposed to ?discuss potential solutions to the scalability and integration challenges (technical and non-technical) to help guide future National Science Foundation (NSF) investments in smart cities deployments.?

The project was successful in achieving the aforementioned goals and objectives. Specifically, through listening sessions and in-person workshop, we identified solutions to the significant technical, policy, and socioeconomic challenges to integration and scaling of connected communities technologies, which is summarized in our final report, Enabling and Sustaining Connected Communities Rooted in Solving Societal Challenges. 

The report focuses on the critical roles in smart and connected communities:

  1. NSF and other funders,
  2. Academia and other research and technology experts, and 
  3. Local governments and other community organizations.

Based on these roles, the report categorized findings into impact areas:

  1. Putting communities in the lead,
  2. Sustaining innovations, and 
  3. Integrating and scaling successful technologies in new communities.

The report outlines potential solutions to challenges integrating and scaling connected communities technologies and provides a potential path forward to funders, researchers, and community leaders to more effectively collaborate to achieve the promise of connected communities technologies. 

Community Collaboration Outcomes and Impact

The success of this project is based on the collaboration with numerous partners. We specifically leveraged the diverse network of over 225 municipal, private and equity partners of Metro21 and Traffic21 Institutes at Carnegie Mellon University (CMU) (https://www.cmu.edu/metro21/partners.html) (https://mobility21.cmu.edu/about/leadership/deployment-partners/). We tapped into the network of MetroLab Network  (https://metrolabnetwork.org/) and reached out to the numerous communities and researchers part of NSF?s Smart and Connected Communities program and listed on their searchable website. The resultant mix of diverse stakeholders spanned the urban, suburban, rural and tribal communities and covered topic areas including climate resilience, ecosystem services, energy, mobility and transportation, and multiple applications.

The design of the project also provided touchpoints to include community input and strengthen the project?s outcomes and impact. The project team organized a series of online listening sessions aimed at highlighting the diverse array of challenges facing connected communities projects and some of the solutions participants had developed. Based on that feedback, the team designed a two-day in-person workshop to optimize feedback from practitioners in government, nonprofits, industry, and academia about possible solutions to challenges facing connected communities projects.

Broader Impact 

Soon after being awarded funding, the project was promoted on the Metro21 bi-monthly newsletter and website project page (https://www.cmu.edu/metro21/projects/equitable-economic-prosperity/solving-societal-challenges-through-sustainable-connected-communities.html). Within six weeks of completing the pre-workshop listening sessions and in-person workshop, the team published the findings in an Executive Summary (https://www.cmu.edu/metro21/news/news-articles/news-articles-2023/images/final-metro-21-nsf-report-executive-summary-23.pdf) and Full Report (https://www.cmu.edu/metro21/news/news-articles/news-articles-2023/images/final-metro-21-nsf-report-final-report-23.pdf), and posted on the Metro21 website. 

The findings were presented at the MetroLab Annual Summit in Portland on June 27, 2023. Several attendees have requested the report for their internal and external audiences - including the Cities of Pittsburgh and San Antonio, Carnegie Mellon University, University of Pittsburgh and the University of Glasgow, Scotland. PI Lightman will continue to share lessons learned through speaking opportunities throughout the year at various national conferences, workshops and webinars.

The report and the Summit presentation were featured in the Metro21 newsletter and findings were posted on social media, including LinkedIn (https://www.linkedin.com/posts/metro21_metro21-releases-report-on-enablingsustaining-activity-7076924768800624642-mdln?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_desktop) (https://www.linkedin.com/posts/thyaga_enabling-and-sustaining-connected-communities-activity-7029619941045608448-1Ur9?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_desktop) and Twitter (https://twitter.com/Metro21CMU/status/1668690803764371493) (https://twitter.com/Metro21CMU/status/1674106748896935936).  

The full report (https://www.cmu.edu/metro21/news/news-articles/news-articles-2023/2023-june/nsf-workshop-final-report.html) and executive summary (https://www.cmu.edu/metro21/news/news-articles/news-articles-2023/images/final-metro-21-nsf-report-executive-summary-23.pdf) will remain publicly available and can be shared widely. 

Funding Impact

The intent of this project is to inform the future funding and investment decisions of public and private organizations, as well as federal agencies such as the NSF. 

Conclusion 

We are grateful for the support of NSF for this project which provides a potential path forward to NSF, academia, and local governments to more effectively collaborate to achieve the promise of connected communities technologies. This project/report is not an end to the conversation. It will be up to NSF, universities, researchers, and local governments to figure out how to put into practice the ideas in this report. Further development of these ideas will benefit from collaborative effort by people working in each of these domains, co-creatively and inclusively. We encourage NSF to support further work to develop these ideas into action and to invest in the promise of connected communities.


 

 


Last Modified: 08/27/2023
Modified by: Karen H Lightman
